revision.text:
{{Infobox military person|name = Andrei Ivanovich Girich|native_name = Андрей Иванович Гирич|birth_date = 28 December 1918|death_date = 11 April 1973|birth_place = [[Yahotyn]], [[Kiev Governorate]]|death_place = [[Monino]], [[Moscow Oblast]], [[Soviet Union]]|allegiance = {{flag|Soviet Union}}|branch = [[Soviet Air Force]]|serviceyears = 1939–1973|rank = [[Major general]]|battles = [[World War II]] *[[Crimean Campaign]] *[[Battle of Debrecen]] *[[Siege of Budapest]] *[[Prague Offensive]]|awards = {{Hero of the Soviet Union}} {{Order of Lenin}}
[[Order of the Red Banner]]
[[Order of Suvorov]] 3rd class
[[Order of the Red Star]] (2)
[[Medal for Battle Merit]]}}'''Andrei Ivanovich Girich''' (Russian: Андрей Иванович Гирич; 28 December 1918 – 11 April 1973) was a Ukrainian [[Soviet Air Forces|Soviet Air Force]] [[major general]] and [[Hero of the Soviet Union]]. Girich claimed at least 17 victories against German aircraft during [[World War II]]. He was a squadron commander in the [[486th Fighter Aviation Regiment]] during the war.{{Ruheroes|name = Andrei Girich|id = 899}}{{Cite web|title = Гирич Андрей Иванович|url = http://soviet-aces-1936-53.ru/abc/g/girich.htm|website = soviet-aces-1936-53.ru|access-date = 2016-01-27|language = Russian|trans-title = Girich Andrei Ivanovich}} == Early life == Girich was born on 28 December 1918 in [[Yahotyn]] to a working class family. He graduated from the [[Kiev River College]] in 1938. Girich learned to fly at the Kiev aeroclub. He also worked as the assistant captain of the ''Leningrad'', a ship operated by the Dnieper River Shipping Company. In 1939, he was drafted into the [[Red Army]] and was sent to the Odessa Military Air College. In 1941, he joined the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]]. {{Cite book|title = Stalin's Falcons|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=kwvzAAAAMAAJ|publisher = Grub Street|date = 1999-01-01|isbn = 9781902304014|language = en|first = Tomas|last = Polak|page = 124}}{{Cite book|title = Герои Советского Союза: Краткий биографический словарь|last = Shkadov|first = I.N.|publisher = Voenizdat|year = 1987|isbn = |location = Moscow|pages = |volume = 1 Abaev-Lubitsch|language = Russian|trans-title = Heroes of the Soviet Union: A Brief Biographical Dictionary|url = http://www.az-libr.ru/index.htm?Persons&000/Src/0006/38ca309f}} == World War II == When [[Operation Barbarossa]] began on 22 June 1941, Girich was a flight leader in the 12th Fighter Aviation Regiment. On 25 June, he shot down a [[Junkers Ju 88]] by frontal attack over [[Ivano-Frankivsk|Stanislaus]]. Girich intercepted and shot down a second Ju 88 over [[Lozova railway station]] on 28 September. In November, the regiment was sent to Crimea. On 5 November, Girich was awarded the [[Order of the Red Star]].Order of the Red Star citation, available online at [https://pamyat-naroda.ru/heroes/podvig-chelovek_nagrazhdenie2023342/ pamyat-naroda.ru] On 26 December, the 12th Fighter Aviation Regiment became the 486th Fighter Aviation Regiment. Girich became a squadron commander in the regiment. On 3 February 1942, he shot down an [[Me-109 fighter|Me 109]] over [[Kerch Strait]]. In the air battle, his squadron shot down three more Me 109s without losing any aircraft. On 16 March, Girich's squadron tangled with twelve German fighters over Kerch Strait. In this engagement, Girich shot down another Me 109. On 9 May, six fighters led by Girich fought an air battle with 40 Me 109s over Karatch. The squadron shot down five Me 109s and Girich gained another victory. {{Cite web|title = Гирич Андрей Иванович – советский военный летчик Герой Советского Союза|url = http://airaces.narod.ru/all3/girich.htm|website = airaces.narod.ru|access-date = 2016-01-28|language = Russian|trans-title = Girich Andrei Ivanovich – Soviet pilots Heroes of the Soviet Union}} After being withdrawn from Crimea, the regiment was sent to Moscow for air defense in August. On 5 November, Girich shot down a [[Heinkel He 111]] over [[Ostashkov]]. In the summer of 1943, the regiment was sent to the [[Central Front (Soviet Union)|Central Front]]. Between 15 July and 8 December, Girich reportedly made 103 sorties, conducted 17 air battles and shot down seven German aircraft. On 4 September, he was awarded the [[Order of the Red Banner]].Order No. 58 16th Air Army, available online at [https://pamyat-naroda.ru/heroes/podvig-chelovek_nagrazhdenie18211246/ pamyat-naroda.ru] On 6 September, he shot down a Ju 88 over Oblozhki. On 21 October, he shot down two Ju 88s over [[Kolpen]] and [[Ostrovy]]. In December, the regiment was sent to the rear for resupply but moved to Oryol in May 1944. It fought in [[Operation Bagration]] and the [[Lublin–Brest Offensive]] during the summer. In August, it transferred to the [[5th Air Army]] and fought in the [[Jassy–Kishinev Offensive]]. On 25 August, Girich shot down a [[Focke-Wulf Fw 190]] over [[Huși]]. On 3 September, he claimed another Fw 190 over [[Ploiești]]. By 20 September, when he was recommended for an award of the title Hero of the Soviet Union, Girich had made 439 sorties and shot down 15 enemy aircraft. On 23 September, he shot down another Fw 190 over [[Turda]]. From October, the regiment fought in the [[Budapest Offensive]]. Girich shot down a Me 190 over [[Isaszeg]] on 17 November. In January 1945, the German forces attempted to resupply Budapest by air. Girich reportedly shot down a [[Junkers Ju 52]]. On 23 February 1945, Girich was awarded the title Hero of the Soviet Union and the Order of Lenin. The regiment then fought in the [[Prague Offensive]] in early May. During the offensive, Girich shot down another German aircraft. On 8 June, he received the [[Order of Suvorov]] 3rd class.Order No. 275 2nd Ukrainian Front, available online at [https://pamyat-naroda.ru/heroes/podvig-chelovek_nagrazhdenie43149800/ pamyat-naroda.ru] According to Mikhail Bykhov, Girich claimed 17 and four shared victories, flew 478 sorties and conducted 84 air battles.{{Cite book|title = Асы Великой Отечественной. Самые результативные летчики 1941–1945 гг.|last = Bykhov|first = Mikhail|publisher = Yauza|year = 2007|isbn = 9785699205264|location = Moscow|pages = 273|url = http://militera.lib.ru/bio/0/pdf/bykov_my01.pdf|language = Russian|trans-title = Aces of the Great Patriotic War: Top scoring pilots, 1941–1945}} == Postwar == Girich continued to serve in the Soviet Air Force after the end of the war. He commanded an aviation division. In 1950, he graduated from the [[Gagarin Air Force Academy|Air Force Academy]]. On 30 December 1946, he was awarded his second Order of the Red Star. Girich graduated from the [[Military Academy of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Russia|Military Academy of the General Staff]] in 1958 with the rank of major general. He was appointed a departmental head in the Air Force Academy shortly afterwards. Girich lived in [[Monino]] and died on 11 April 1973. == References == {{DEFAULTSORT:Girich, Andrei}} [[Category:1918 births]] [[Category:1973 deaths]] [[Category:Soviet Air Force generals]] [[Category:Soviet major generals]] [[Category:People from Yahotyn]] [[Category:Soviet World War II flying aces]] [[Category:Soviet military personnel of World War II from Ukraine]] [[Category:Heroes of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Lenin]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Red Banner]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Suvorov, 3rd class]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Red Star]] [[Category:General Staff Academy (Soviet Union) alumni]]
